reasoning:
First and foremost, I have to say that streaming media—Netflix in particular—lies well outside my circle of competence. As I’ve often noted, “Risk comes from not knowing what you’re doing,” and I simply don’t claim to understand the economics of content studios, subscriber algorithms and the cutthroat world of Hollywood. Without reliable fundamentals, moat analysis, management track record or intrinsic value estimates, I can’t tell whether Netflix has a durable competitive advantage or is merely chasing market share with ever-increasing content spend. 

From what little we know, Netflix faces an uphill battle maintaining pricing power against a flood of competitors. Its content library is expensive to build and easy to replicate; there’s no meaningful switching cost that would keep me confident of long-term subscriber retention. We have zero insight here into balance sheet strength or consistent earnings—just “insufficient data” across the board—which raises a big red flag for me on financial health. 

Management may be talented at building subscriber counts, but we have no visibility into their capital allocation or stewardship of shareholder capital. With no credible valuation or margin of safety, there’s simply no way to determine an intrinsic value, so I’d be guessing at the price I’m paying. 

When I compare this to holding stakes in businesses like Coca-Cola, Apple or GEICO—where I understand the business, see durable moats and sensible management—I’d rather own a wonderful business at a fair price than a fair business at a wonderful price. In this case, Netflix doesn’t clear those hurdles for me, so my signal is bearish. Investing without a margin of safety is a recipe for permanent loss, and I’d rather sit on the sidelines.

moat_analysis.details: Insufficient data for comprehensive moat analysis

pricing_power_analysis.details: Insufficient data for pricing power analysis

book_value_analysis.details: Insufficient data for book value analysis
